Posts.Content: Done. Now we wait. This morning was my last radiation treatment. I brought the doughnuts. On one hand, yay, me, I graduated. On the other, it was anticlimactic. The session itself was just like the others, including the interruption to restart a computer. Then I met with one of the nurses. I have a follow-up appointment there in a few weeks, and theyll check my PSA level. She also said that just like the side effects took some time to start, they may take some time to pass. This is not what I wanted to hear. Ive had a catheter in for weeks because of the swollen prostate, and Im so ready for it to be out. But it take take some time for things to return to normal. Normal  they keep using that word. I do not think it means what you think it means. I also got a gimme cup from the hospital. My urologists office is about five minutes from home. Ill go there tomorrow morning and play the game, where I get the cath pulled out, go home, and see what happens. If nothing, I go back and have it shoved back in (ouch!). I also have some Depends on hand, just in case.

This morning, that 'PI$$ NOW OR DIE!' feeling has lessened to something more normal. I still have to go a lot, and it's still not as productive, but there is some improvement. Posts.Title: Day 17 of Forty

Posts.Content: Proton radiation IMRT If someone tells you that you cannot have radiation treatments with a urinary catheter in place, dont you believe him! For the past four sessions, Ive gone to my urologists office to have a catheter removed. Then Ive gone to my morning radiation treatment, gone home, and seen how the day went. My prostate is still too swollen for me to pee without a cath. About mid-afternoon, I end up back at my urologists office to get another catheter put in  and the nurse drains off an average of four hundred milliliters. All because my urologist hadnt confirmed with my radiation oncologist about the whole nuke-me with-a-catheter-in-place thing. Did I mention how painful pushing or pulling a catheter through a swollen prostate can be? I did, in my last posting here. The morals here are that first , you cannot ask too many stupid questions, and second, take charge of your own treatment.

Posts.Title: Fifteen days left of forty

Posts.Content: Day 17 of forty Proton radiation IMRT The treatments themselves are boringly routine. Arrive with a full bladder, change into scrub pants, wait to be called, lay down on the slab, get CT scanned, get irradiated, rinse repeat…. I haven’t mentioned the blast door. There is a sliding door that closes off the treatment room. It looks right out of Star Wars – two-feet thick. I guess they’re serious about keeping those pesky protons where they are. Wednesdays are ‘visit the doctor day’. I’m still struggling to pee. I gave a urine sample, to see if I have an infection. Maybe that’s why I have such a hard time peeing. I wouldn’t be surprised. After all, I got e-coli from getting the markers inserted. He also gave me a prescription for Ambien to put me to sleep at night (instead of waking five-plus times to try to pee). We’re swapping that out for a prescription for Sonota. Between my wife, her two girls, and me, our household is proof of greater living through chemistry. My sex life lives! I still get a good erection and ejaculation. How do I know? MYOB!

Posts.Title: Day 17 of Forty

Posts.Content: Howdy, y'all... I didn't see a new member sticky. As the title says, I'm new to this. It's still sinking in with my wife and me. The urologist is great. His matter-of-fact attitude is actually relaxing to me. But I don't know how big of a deal to make of all this. About thirty years ago, mom lost both breasts to cancer, and then about seven years ago small-sell lung cancer took her too early. That's one reason my dad was so emotional with I told him. We meet with a radiologist in a couple of weeks to discuss options, and then meet with a surgeon to also discuss. Then I have to choose which route to take. I thing it's the 'have to' that pi$$e$ me off the most. That, and how this threatens my sex life with my sexy wife.

Posts.Title: new to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Yesterday was a very disappointing day. Twenty days ago was my last session of IMRT. The only side effect Ive had is swollen prostate  to the point that I could not pee through it. That started about halfway through my forty treatments. Ive had a catheter ever since. About once a week we play a game. I go to my urologists office (about five minutes away) and have the nurse pull it out. Damn, that hurts. Then we wait and see. Yesterday was a very disappointing day. We started in the morning. I made it to mid-afternoon when I was back to have the catheter put back in. Damn, that really hurt! I drained 520ml -- a new personal record. My initial research online says that this swelling could continue anywhere from two to six weeks after treatment. Im halfway there. To say that having the catheter hanging from my penis is uncomfortable is like saying a stick of dynamite is a firecracker. I walk more gingerly, Im limited to only a few positions to sleep, and heaven forbid I get sexually aroused! For now, I continue on the steady diet of two Rapaflo a day, six ibuprofen a day, and cranberry juice. My wife had me try some of her CBD oil, and her sister gave me some prostate health pills from AdvoCare. I wonder which of these is actually helping. I wonder which may be hurting.

Posts.Title: Day 20 of forty

Posts.Content: Sixteen treatments of forty left Proton radiation IMRT My treatments are fairly routine. The side effects are not. As were irradiating an organ, its reacting, irritated, becoming inflamed and swelling. Naturally. Whats not expected is the extant to the swelling. My prostate has closed off my urethra. Last weekend was Mothers Day weekend. As is out tradition, we spent Sunday at Scarborough Renaissance Festival in Waxahachie, Texas, just south of Dallas. The days leading up to it, peeing had actually improved, and the day at the faire went well, although I visited every privy, often. The catheter By Wednesday early morning, I had diarrhea, and peeing became more difficult. I skipped my treatment that morning. By Wednesday night, I hadnt produced urine for over eight hours, and my wife took me to the hospital ER. They took me for treatment very quickly. The first thing they did was put a catheter in me. THIS WAS THE MOST PAINFUL THING IVE EVER HAD. They heard me scream in the other treatments rooms. And they drained over half a litter. They also took blood. As it turned out, I did not have any infection. Save for the prostate pinching off my urethra, Im healthy. As my wife and I were getting ready to leave, my urologist came in. Hed reviewed everything, but didnt make any changes. According to him, I could not have the catheter in during my radiation treatment, so he wanted me to come to his office at 7am the next day (Thursday) to have the catheter removed. THIS WAS THE SECOND MOST PAINFUL THING IVE EVER HAD. I dont understand how anyone can self-catheterize. I went to my radiation treatment that morning, and stayed home, hoping Id never have to be catheterized again. No such luck. I went back to my urologists office Thursday afternoon to have a catheter put in again. The lanacane helped a little  very little. I screamed slightly less as it passed through my swollen prostate. I repeated the same process on Friday. While Id managed to squeeze out a few drops, but the time I got another catheter in that afternoon, another half-liter poured out. The kilt I mentioned our day at a Renaissance faire. Im a big fan of wearing a kilt, and not just at the faires. In this case, with a tube hanging from my penis down the side of my leg, a kilt helps. By Friday afternoon, when I had a catheter put in again, I quizzed the nurse more. For my situation, I do not need a bag. Unless theres a reason to collect urine, theres no need for a bad, leg or otherwise. A simple cap on the end of the tube does fine. I feel the urge to pee as natural. Its like artificial peeing, bypassing a lot of the systems between the bladder and the toilet. Also, I taped the tube to my thigh during the night so it doesnt flop around and get caught while I try to sleep. Now, Saturday afternoon, Ive had a catheter in since yesterday afternoon. I slept okay last night. With just the tube hanging, its almost manageable. I can pee, artificially, and its weird. I have to remind myself that its safe to drink. The hope is that I leave the catheter in all weekend. Monday morning Ill go to my urologists office to have it removed  remember: I cant have a treatment with a catheter in place. Hopefully over this weekend, the meds and diet will have some effect on my swollen prostate. If not, Ill have to come up with something. I can hardly drive, let alone stay at the office throughout the day, and thered only so much work I can do from home. My radiology oncologist has had me double-down on the alpha blocker, taking it twice a day. He and my urologist both think that Im a one-percenter. Im the guy whos bound and determined to run the gamut of everything that could go badly with this treatment. My body seems to just sluff off what meds they give me. Ill probably give them a couple of white papers to publish. As for diet, Im drinking cranberry juice and snacking on dark chocolate covered almonds. My wife has also found a good smoothie recipe with turmeric. I post here not to influence anyone investigating what course of action to take, but to tell what my individual experiences are. As they say: your mileage may vary. We soldier on

Posts.Title: Sixteen treatments of forty left

Posts.Content: Yesterday was day one of forty. As this was my first treatment, I was to be there early. I changed into the scrub pants, leaving my pants and shoes in a locker, and waited in a small waiting room. One man was there for his last treatment. The tech went over a few things (mostly repeating herself). I laid out on the table and the machines started moving around me -- this was the freakiest part. This included x-rays to match up with the initial CT scan. Then the actual treatment. One of the parts rotated around me twice. This all took about ten minutes. Once this was done, the tech came back, reminded me what time the rest of my visit would happen. She also 'tattooed' small marks in the place of the temporary sharpie marks: a small needle to put freckle-like marks on my skin. (I've got tattoos; I wasnt impressed.) Back to the lockers to use the restroom! They want a full bladder each time. And I'm on Dulcolx and Gas-X, once a day, while I'm undergoing treatment. Relatively easy. At this point, I don't feel any different. Today was day two of forty. First, Ive been using a wrong term. Im not undergoing ERBT (external beam radiation therapy), but IMRT (intensity-modulated radiation therapy). The difference is subtle, but important. The worst part of this mornings visit was the traffic! I was forty-five minutes late. Fortunately, I wasnt the only late arrival. The staff shuffled the deck and managed to get me in. Procedures same as yesterday (and tomorrow, I'm sure, and the next day, too). The tech did remove the stickers from the temporary marks, now that Ive got tattoos, and I couldnt scrub them off in the shower this morning. And its Wednesday, which is see the doctor day. After only two treatments, I had nothing to report. See ya next Wednesday, doc. Tomorrow is my annual physical with my GP. Im sure well have lots to discuss.

Posts.Title: forty days

Posts.Content: Day 14 of forty Proton radiation IMRT. Today is Friday. Last Wednesday was day 12 - another weekly visit with the doctor day. Ive waited a couple of days to post an update in order to see what happens with the doctors latest prescription. The treatments are routine now. All but boring. Its less than ten minutes on the slab. Im grumpy. Im grumpy because Im not getting enough sleep, and because my body is straining each time I try to pee. Meanwhile, Im getting one hekuva core workout. If you throw protons at an organ, that organ tends to get inflamed and may swell. As my urethra passes through my swollen prostate, its constricted. Urinating is a real struggle right now. At first my doc had me add ibuprofen to my regimen. Its good for inflammation. But its hardly touched this. Two days ago he added a prescription for alfuzosin, an alpha blocker, meant to relax the muscles around my bladder and prostate. After two doses, its barely taken the edge off. The doc said I should see some results in as little as a couple of hours. WebMD says it may take one or two days. Im hoping its something thatll build up in my system. One of the other men in the morning waiting room group graduated today  his last treatment. He brought a fruit plate. When my graduation comes, Im planning on chocolate-iced doughnuts with sprinkles.

Posts.Title: Day 14 of forty

Posts.Content: Day twenty-eight of forty...? I say day twenty-eight. There seems to be some confusion at the doctors office about exactly what day is my last. It doesnt help the calendar that I missed a treatment (because I couldnt pee) and that the office is closed for business on Memorial Day Monday. They should know. Life with a urinary catheter. Why dont I just self-cath? Simple: because the pain of pushing a swizzle straw through my overly-swollen prostate is prohibitive. They can leave this thing in safely for a month, but Im done in two and a half weeks. I walk a little funny, slowly, gingerly, and I avoid stairs. I can even drive my manual transmission car. I occasionally have a sting or a burn or a tug. It also feels like I dont have much a penis left. Im seriously considering a sex therapist, kinda like a physical therapist after an injury. I did a bit of MacGyvering: The big collection bag they sent home with me had a valve on it to empty. I took that valve off the bag they sent home and stuck it on the end of the catheter, where there was just a plug. So much easier. Yesterday was the weekly visit with the doctor day. I had it out with him. Whats the better alpha-blocker? I have been on Alfuzosin for the past four weeks, and its done nothing for me. Over a year ago, when I first met my urologist, he put me on an antibiotic and Rapaflo, treating this as prostatitis, just to eliminate that possibility. I hated it. I hated it because it worked on me, to the point that I could not ejaculate. Im a little past that relatively minor issue today. So Im back on Rapaflo. My radiology oncologist said, why not? Hes still busy being astounded that I have such a swollen prostate and thats not acting as he expects. This morning as I drove away from the pharmacy, I seemed to recall that the Rapaflo made me a nauseous, too. Hmm -- I hadnt considered that. In the mens waiting room, fruit may be healthier, but doughnuts move faster.

Posts.Title: Day twenty-eight of forty

Posts.Content: Day thirty-five of forty. Five more treatments to go. The downhill slide Im so ready for this to be done. Its not the treatments. Theyre a piece of cake: get up a little early, go to the hospital, drop my drawers, lay on the slab, get zapped, get a doughnut, go to work. Easy-peasy, kegal squeezy. No, its the swelling. My prostate doesnt appreciate having protons tossed at it, so it responds by swelling up -- so much that its cut off my urethra. A mans gotta pee, and Ive been doing that with a catheter for about three weeks. Just a week and a half left and I try to live a normal life, without a swizzle straw up my dinglehopper. Exit plan My urologist and I have an end game in mind. Itll be weird trying to walk and sleep and pee and be with my wife like a human again. I keep up with the ibuprofen and Rapaflo (alpha blocker), plus the turmeric smoothies and cranberry juice. The day after my last treatment Ill have the catheter pulled out, and well see how that goes. At worst, by the end of that day itll go back in, and we play the game again the next day. At best, freedom! My wife had me pick a nightgown for her that first night back. I love my wife! The visit the doctor days have been moved to Mondays. Ill see my radiation oncologist in a few days. Hes on vacation this week  lucky SOB. Its a rum & Dr. Pepper evening. Iechyd da!

Posts.Content: I had a little experience with my PC. A week ago last Thursday morning I had the markers put in before starting EBRT in a few weeks. The next day, Friday afternoon I started feeling flu-like symptoms. The on-call doc from my urology group called in an Rx, but also strongly recommended going to the ER. Saturday morning I did. I was in the hospital being treated for sepsis until last Wednesday. I don't really consider this a set-back. More of an annoyance. My urologist said this happens 2% nationally, 1 in 300 in their group. I should get a lotto ticket while I'm defying the odds...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Radiation and surgery have roughly equal successful outcomes. But the "downside" could come if you experience a recurrence. With surgery, you have the fall-back option of salvage radiation to solidify a cure. With radiation as primary treatment, there are little to no fall-back options to a cure.... Actually, I've been told the differently, by two doctors, and my own research backs up the idea, that after radiation, surgery may still be an option.

Posts.Content: The swelling continues The only side effect Ive seen from the treatments is a swollen prostate  to the point that I cannot pee. Ive had a catheter off and on for a little over four weeks. Yesterday morning we played the game again  the one in which the urologists nurse pulls out the catheter (ow!), and we see how things go One time before, my urologist said he wanted me to drink plenty of water. He also wanted me to suffer before giving up and putting a catheter back in. I did what I was told. I drank water, and I did suffer. I went back up to his office just after lunch, suffering. When the nurse put the catheter back in (oww!), I drained 500 ml. Hes on vacation next week, so the cath stays in for a little over a week this time. Maybe things will relax and open up. Maybe Ill really be able to celebrate the Fourth of July

Posts.Title: Nine days after IMRT

Posts.Content: Two more treatments left -- Wednesday... The most exciting part of todays treatment was that they had to restart a computer  twice. Meh. I just waited on the slab. It was a visit the doctor day. He said he appreciates that Im being such a sport about the difficulties  of having a catheter in for the past two-and-a-half weeks. Umyeah. Meanwhle, insurance is being difficult about my Rapaflo prescription. Sure, my doc has prescribed it differently than usual. What of it? Ive got three pills left. My doc and I are of differing opinions as to how long Ill have problems urinating once treatments are done. Hes warned me I could still be with a cath for a couple of more weeks. I dont think so I mentioned a few posts ago that Id macgyvered the catheter, putting a valve on it for easier use. Heres a tip: remember to close the valve before you go back to bed in the dead of the night. Your laundry will thank you.

Posts.Title: Day thirty-eight of forty

Posts.Content: Day seven of forty. The treatments are fairly routine now. Im not a morning person, though, and I dont like leaving the bed so early (my lovely wife is there, after all). Two things Ive notice: one, peeing is a little more difficult, erratic, and less productive. Two: while I dont think Im feeling fatigue yet, I do have a general mellow feeling, almost as if I didnt get a good nights sleep. Wednesdays are visit the doctor day, when they weight me and check blood pressure and pulse (I have one, thanks), and just check into see how things are going. I mentioned the two issues to him. The peeing issue isnt uncommon. Were irritating an organ, after all, and some inflammation will happen. Hes added ibuprofen to my regimen: two 200mg pills in the morning and two at night, for a total of 800mg, to help control the inflammation. That should take a couple of days to work. If it doesnt, hes got a prescription that will  a muscle relaxant. I should have asked him more about that point. Way back when, when I first saw my urologist, he tried treating this as prostatitis, with an antibiotic and a muscle relaxant. I hated the muscle relaxant. It relaxed EVERYTHING down there, which made an active sex life much less active. The mellow feeling: I get home from work and want a nap. I cannot do a full ninety minute tae kwon do class without stepping out to catch my breath. Last night was truly a dark and stormy night, so I know I didnt get enough sleep (I was busy trying to pee). However, the doctor thinks that it probably isnt related to the radiation treatments  not this early in the forty days. Remember: I got the markers inserted into my prostate, in preparation for these radiation treatments. I was a rarity. I beat the odds and got a major infection. E.coli. Five days in the hospital. While that was three weeks ago, my body is probably still recovering from that, and I should keep reminding myself of that. Continuing with the Dulcolax and GasX once a day, and vitamin D3, and add the ibuprofen. Otherwise, business as usual. Im waiting on the auto shop to call me back to tell my why my check engine light is on.

Posts.Title: Day seven of forty

Posts.Content: Theres no rush, but Ive made my decision. Im going with radiation treatment  the nuclear option. I could go into all the details how my wife and I looked at the possible side effects of surgery versus radiation versus the status of my cancer. I could also describe how each post I read here about someones surgery introduces doubt. But the wheels are now in motion. Theres a single pill, an antibiotic, sitting on the bathroom counter. Its a little something I have to take two hours before I see my urologist again. When I do see him again, itll to be so that he can insert three fiducials in my prostate. (Another experience with anal probing.) Its a precipice. Once I take that horse pill, theres no going back. Well, thats not true. Im sure that at any time, I could call off the whole nuke it from orbit thing, and let a surgeon make Julian fries out of my innards. Instead, Ill let a technician point a proton accelerator (just like out of Ghostbusters, almost) and take aim at my manhood. Im just now getting to where theres less blood in my semen. And the next step, at best, is no semen?! Whiskey Tango Foxtrot....! Its just that Ive never jumped out of an airplane before. I dont know whats on the other side.

Posts.Title: choosing radiation

Posts.Content: My wife didnt go with me when I had the biopsy. Im glad she wasnt; it was quite an experience. But she was there in the doctors office with me when he told me the news. I couldnt ask for a better partner and advocate. She and I told her kids later that day (mixed family), and her parents. I called my dad a few days later. I told my son when I had him for the weekend a few days after that. For some reason, I waited to tell my sister. My dad outed me to her, and she sent me an emotional text message. Then I finally called my twenty year old daughter at college. Once the immediate family, I made a big announcement on Facebook, just to get it out of the way. And now, Im dragging my feet on telling my bosses. This thing wont have much effect on work, I dont expect, except for the daily time of treatment (Im 95% sure Im choosing radiation, nuking the thing). But why am I being so shy? Theres a woman engineer here who had breast cancer (yay, pink ribbon  whatever). She had a mastectomy. Ever since then, one of the secretaries here has made a big deal of some annual walk with Susan G Komen. I dont think for a minute Ill get that kind of attention.

Posts.Content: Back on the catheter. I so enjoyed the 36 hour reprieve. I went back to my urologist yesterday, though, and the nurse put an ultrasound to my abdomen. The day before it was at 200 ml, and my doc sent me home. Yesterday is was at 302. While I had been peeing, a little, some drops, a timid stream here and there, it wasnt enough. Well tee it up again on Monday. Patience.

Posts.Title: Three days after forty days of IMRT

Posts.Content: Day thirty-one of forty After this morning, nine more treatments. (Yes, Im counting down!) One of the treatment machines was down today. Us guys were backed up in the waiting area. I didnt mind the forty-five minute wait. As I looked around the waiting area, I was struck by two thoughts: I'm so much younger than anyone here, and I'm now the most' tenured' in these treatments. The issue Ive been having with peeing isnt going away. My urologist, his nurse, and I have figured out that its all in the prostate, swollen by the treatments. Everything else along my urinary track seems to be working just fine. Still, Ive had a catheter in full-time for the past two weeks. Its manageable. For the record, this problem trying to pee through a swollen prostate is the only problem I've had -- but it's a big problem. Another visit the doctor day. Not much help there. My radiology oncologist suggested that maybe how full my bladder gets may be contributing to my problem. Maybe if I drink less, but more frequently, things might flow better. Meanwhile, Im on a steady diet of Rapaflo, ibuprofen, turmeric shakes, and cranberry juice. My radiology oncologist disappointed me in another way today, too. How can anyone whos lived in Dallas so long not know about Scarborough Renaissance Festival?

Posts.Title: Day thirty-one of forty

Posts.Content: FREEDOM.! My last IMRT session, of forty, was yesterday. Both my radiology oncology doctor and his nurse had warned, saying, well, you know it took a while for the swelling to start; its liable to take some time for it to start to go down. You may have to have the catheter for a little longer Oh yeah? Try one day longer! Early this morning I went to my urologists office to play the game, where the nurse removes the catheter, and we see how the day goes. Worst case, Id go back in the afternoon and have it put back in. I took today off from work for this event. I went home and had a small glass of cranberry juice and a cup of coffee. And I waited. I also mowed the backyard. I peed. A little. Steady drops. Almost a stream. Lunchtime passes, and Im doing okay. Of course it stings and burns to pee: Ive had a swizzle straw up my dinglehopper for three weeks. But Im peeing. By mid-afternoon I get concerned that I'm not voiding enough. Im aware of my bladder, but Im not uncomfortable. It was getting late, and it was decision time. I went to my urologists office. The nurse ultra-sounded my bladder to measure the volume. While its got urine, its less than half whats usually drained when I get catheterized. She called the doctor. He said he didnt want my catheterized, not for that small amount. I got rejected by my urologist! He happens to be the on-call doc tonight, so if all else fails he gets to be the one to put it back in. I dont think so! Ill struggle with low-flow before getting the cath again. After getting the catheter out this morning, the first thing my wife and I did was to confirm that I do not have ED. Never you mind how; MYOB!

Posts.Title: One day after IMRT

Posts.Content: I had a quarterly PSA test last week. My favorite nurse called me this morning. My prostate continues to decline. My last session of IMRT (of forty sessions) was last June 8. A month later, my PSA was 2.22. In October it was 1.21. Today is at 0.72. I chose radiation after my wife and I did the research. From what we found, the success rate between da Vinci surgery and IMRT was all but the same, with similar risks of incontinence and erection. But to us, IMRT was much less invasive. It hasnt been without challenges. My little glad didnt take kindly to being irradiated. Halfway into my treatments my prostate responded by swelling up  so much so that I had to have a catheter just to empty my bladder. After about eight weeks of having a swizzle straw up my diglehopper, my urologist and I had had enough and took it up a notch. He stabbed me in the gut to put in a suprapubic catheter. This was to let things below my bladder relax and heal. That took about five weeks. That was pulled out in September. Its still a challenge to pee, but its manageable. And I can still get it up, although the strength of my erection hasnt fully recovered. My wife and I are still enjoying a healthy, happy romp in bed when our busy lives allow.

Posts.Title: 226 days after IMRT, PSA declining

Posts.Content: Its been an interesting couple of weeks. While Im thirty-nine days out from my last IMRT session, Ive had a catheter in for about six weeks now. The only side effect Ive had is a swollen prostate  to the point that I cant pee without the cath. The Fourth of July I spent at the side of my in-laws pool while the rest of the family splashed and frolicked. Yes, I couldve gotten in the pool with the cath, but I dont like it being seen. The Wednesday after that, we played the game again, when I go to my urologist to have the catheter pulled out (ouch), and we see how the day goes. It didnt go well, and I was back there that afternoon to have the catheter put back in so I could pee (ouch!). However, this time the same nurse wasnt there. Shed gotten called away to another office in the group. The nurse I got, and the other doctor (not my usual) didnt have a clue. I had a hard time relating my story to him since my bladder was close to bursting. This was actually a good thing. In effect, I suddenly got a second opinion. The other doctor ordered a contrast CT scan and took a urine sample to check for infection. He went ahead and put my on cypro for an antibiotic. The CT scan happened two days later. With the contrast, that was a weird experience. The tech there also took blood to culture. The results: for one, I have a swollen prostate (no Sierra-Hotel-India-Tango, Sherlock), but nothing else. No cyst or strange growths. Secondly, I have an infection. For this particular bug, cypro is the antibiotic of choice. I met with radiology oncologist (the doc in charge of killing my cancer with IMRT) last Tuesday. He was actually encouraged by both the CT scan and infection. The infection would easily explain why the prostate hasnt relaxed yet. I also had a blood draw there, for my first PSA post IMRT. He warned me that the infection would probably skew the PSA results. My PSA is 2.22. Thats the lowest its ever been recorded. He doesnt want to see me until next year. Ill see my regular urologist in October for another PSA. But I did see my urologist the next day (last Wednesday). We wanted to talk about this whole mess with him. Of the fifty-five doctors in this practice, hes consulted with three others, plus my radiology oncologist. Ive been quite the topic of conversation. Everyones of the opinion that time is the best remedy for this swollen prostate. No need for TURP or other action  yet. If it doesnt clear up in a couple of weeks, I have to consider a super-pelvic catheter. I dont like that idea. Meanwhile, Ive been on cypro for almost two weeks, going after the infection that might be the source of the swollen prostate. And Ive had a curious development. How likely is it that Ill have urine leaking around the catheter if the prostate is still swollen? We play the game again next Wednesday, and although Ive been here before, Im cautiously optimistic.

Posts.Title: Family History?

Posts.Content: This morning I went to my urologist to have the three fiducials, three small gold bbs, inserted into my prostate. His office is in the professional building attached to a hospital. There are other tenants, including a breast cancer center. I suppose the breast cancer center is the major tenant in the building; why else would they have the first ten parking spaces reserved? Complete with pink wheel-stops. But really? Ive got cancer, too. Why dont I get special treatment? Complete with light blue wheel-stops? WTF? This mornings procedure when as expected: very uncomfortable. Its like passing three kidney stones while being anally probed. AS Ive chosen radiation therapy, this was the most invasive part of this whole mess. I have a CT scan simulation scheduled for next Thursday.
